Sexuality is neither chosen nor changed. I agree with that, naturally, it isn't chosen or changed. It just happens naturally. But, there are some questioms left unanswered. For one, could sexuality be related in significant degree to gender identity. Of course, it obviously couldn't be dictative of it, but does that have a role to play, or even vice versa? Kinda like a game of "what came first?" Chicken or the Egg? Another good question would be a situation where a person is intimate enough with their own  emotions to consciously gauge their sexuality and choose to try something new, like a heterosexual being bi-sexual or homosexual becoming bi-sexual. Considering that many people with these sexualities share some psychological traits, how would these traits change? Would they be altered or just added upon? Would the person making a conscious and enlightened decision to spread out their sexuality be changing, or would they just find what they always preferred but didn't realize making them already the sexuality they were going to choose? But what if they revert back in another conscious decision? Would that mean the years they spent as gay after going straight actually have had that persom be straight despite their sexual encounters during all these years? Are people really born gay or straight when we all start in a womb with the same body parts and tools omitting special cases and the obvious? Where does philosophy stop and science start here? Vice versa? Are you seeing why it isn't appropriate to make claims that we don't have definitive proof for yet? Nobody has even asked these questions in the appropriate settings, but that doesn't mean they aren't necessary to finding answers and actually understanding what sexuality is and what purpose it serves. It's easy to put something together, but in science specifically, one flaw and it all falls apart. Don't get me started on polygamy, which we  vilify primarily to ancient and ancient religious beliefs when there is nothong saying that a state of love can't exist between three or four people, ir asexuality which is by far ome of the most inspiring sexualities I have seen, considering they are fewer in comparison. Or maybe I was thinking of pansexual? Probably both.

I'm a woman. A few years ago I was very addicted to slash fan fictions where protagonists (most often two men) get it on with each other (which doesn't really happen in the series). As I read a ton of those fan fictions, I began to develop an aversion to heterosexual sex (or at least the description of it). In a way I was obsessed with male homosexuality, but unable to reconcile that with my own female existence. Maybe that also had something to do with me being a virgin at the time, I wasn't too sure of my own sexuality. Long story short, that was a phase. I don't read fan fictions any more, not that I don't think they're good, the habit just passed me. And I have a boyfriend now and I'm pretty sure I'm straight. The point is, and this may be controversial, but I think stuff we see can influence our mentality about sex and sexuality quite a lot. I mean, I thought for a period of time I was gonna become a voyeur for homosexual experiences (watching gay couples have sex in real life, not just watching porn) to get all my satisfaction. Can I just ask this question? Here's the problem I have. Let's say you are a completely homosexual human being. That means you don't have or want to have sex with anyone on the other side. If that is a genetic trait, why would that genetic trait, that cannot be passed on, survive? It's not possible according to basic evolution. To me, this means, there has to be some sort of a scale, where you're on one side only so far, in terms of gender, but you do have to choose a side. So if it's not genetic, and I don't believe it's possible based on what I've just explained, then it must be something else. You can say it's environmental, but that wouldn't explain case studies where one twin is hetero and another, with the exact same DNA, and upbringing, would be gay. And I have seen it before and it's not that uncommon.

But we all know it is clearly, NOT, a choice. Even if we wanted to not choose it, we would be lying to ourselves, and that is the real paradox. It cannot be both genetic and a choice. It has to be something else. It is part of who we are.

If you want my personal guess, it's got to be that the concept of love has found a way to transcend evolution, rules, and obstacles. Love is complex and can take many forms, but in the end it is really all the same thing, and although we cannot measure it, or define it by science, we still all know what it is.

Love has found a way to break the theory (law, depending on who you talk to...) of evolution.

This video has major inaccuracies: it ignores new and old research to recite the unscientific "born that way" idea about an individual's gay-straight position on the sexual orientation spectrum. It acknowledges cultural influences on sexual activity while denying a place for culture and life experiences in shaping our basic orientation.

A quick thought experiment should show why "born this way" doesn't make sense, even before doing any scientific research: humans are a social species that lives in cultures that vary massively in the role and expression of sexuality sanctioned by culture (think ancient Greece vs. Saudi Arabia, or the Chinese Mouso vs. Victorian England). Having a sexual orientation that was biologically fixed at/before birth and being unable to respond to the culture that person would need to survive in would be a massive (evolutionary and personal) disadvantage. From an evolutionary point of view, we have to have (some) flexibility to adapt to culturally sanctioned sex, because our survival and reproduction could depend on it.

"Evolution's Rainbow", authored by a top Transgender biologist, gives an overview of the nature/nurture science (spoiler - biological differences between people who are a kinsey 0 or 6 can be found, but, they are neither necessary nor sufficient to explain the differences - environment is the explanation). For example, in ancient Greece and Rome, most men had same-sex sexual contact and love between men was considered "better" than that between man and women. Were these men biologically different to modern western men where 90-95% declare they are "straight" (or mostly straight)? No. So, men aren't born with sexuality directed that strongly towards either men or women, both, towards specific activities, fetishes, etc: humans are massively adaptable and malleable at birth.

More detailed research on environmental impacts on sexuality include:
> Gordon and Silva published a 2014 paper about how psychological mechanisms that may explain why people inhabit different positions on the sexual orientation landscape.
> Recent research by Roberts, Glymour and Koenen (2014) recently published research on the long-known correlation between childhood sexual abuse and adult homosexuality: their study found that the abuse affected sexual orientation, rather than orientation (or some other common factor) triggering the abuse.

Note: pointing out the above is not to pathologise same-sex sexuality - the fact that 90+% of people in western society say they are straight is no less a subjective, cultural phenomenon or anymore "valid" a sexuality. But the science shows childhood environment does shape adult sexual attraction. This video ignores new and old research to recite the unscientific "born that way" idea about an individual's gay-straight position on the sexual orientation spectrum.

I don't see much evidence for your stance on sexuality. You make claims that imply everyone thinks it's biological, but don't actually say so. I think that's dishonest.

You say that we still don't fully understand sexuality, which is true. But we can also be certain that it's not purely genetic. If it was, the gay population in the West wouldn't be seeing the dramatic rise that it does today. Skeptics claim these people were all in the closet in the past, but that doesn't account for how rapid the rise has been. Nor does a purely biological model account for the tendency of men to be either gay or straight, while women are much more likely than men to be bisexual. As we know, the primary differences between men and women are hormonal, not genetic. Nor does a purely biological model account for the fact that one finds proportionally more homosexuality in large populations than in small ones. Most importantly, a biological model doesn't account for our inability to identify a "gay" gene. Even though people with gay siblings are more likely to be gay themselves, there so far has been no genetic difference identified between people of different sexualities.

All of the evidence we have at the present points clearly in one direction: homosexuality is a combination of nature and nurture. Some people under some circumstances turn out gay or bisexual. That doesn't make it a choice, as few people decide their sexuality. That doesn't make it a genetic phenomenon that we might one day control through genetic engineering, either.

Sexuality is more similar to a person's musical preferences than it is to either a biological consequence or a voluntary choice. Culture has an influence, but there's no way to control it right now. It just happens.

In the YouTube video “Let’s Talk About Sex: Crash Course Psychology #27” the topic of sex as both an action and a biological identifier is discussed by the creator, Hank Green.  While Green looks at the act of sex, the definitions of sex, and sexual orientation through a psychological viewpoint, one can just as easily look at the same issues through an anthropological lens.  Through fieldwork and research, anthropologists can figure out how the culture they are studying defines sex in relation to gender and the roles each sex is predominantly placed in.   How the culture separates the sexes into roles also affects how each sex is treated.  For example, in a culture where the male members hunt while the female members cook a female who identifies as male may be ostracized and shunned.  In contrast, in a culture where skill is valued over biological sex the female who identifies as male may be accepted.  Green mentions this by discussing how members of a society can be “made to feel miserable for liking certain things or being attracted to certain people” (8:24).  Green’s comment brings up not only females and males identifying as a gender outside of their biological sex but also the sexual orientation of the members of the society.  In a society where the majority of members are heterosexual there can be prejudice and social stigma placed on being homosexual, asexual, or any other sexuality that does not conform.  The way a culture views a certain biological sex, the roles the culture gives to each sex, and the traditional values the culture has when it comes to sexual orientation are all important to an anthropologist researching the culture. 

(The response quiz I did for my Cultural Anthropology course)

To all the people commenting, let me say a few things. First, you should not watch this video on its own. It is called Crash Course, and makes a lot of references to previous videos. If you think he glossed over something, it was probably touched on in previous episodes as well. Second, this is Psychology. It is a soft science, and while psychologists speak as if they have the answer, and the answers they give are usually generally accepted by the psychological community, the human condition is constantly changing. Psychology openly admits that it does not have all the answers, and that the answers it has aren't 100% fact (hence, a "soft" science. A "hard" science would be something like math, which has constants). Knowing this, psychology still has to be taught somehow, which is why it has these generally accepted "truths." If you actually listen to the video, he says that a lot still remains to be understood, and uses phrases such as "generally accepted." Lastly, this is "Crash Course." It's meant to be a quick reference guide, or a tool to be used in addition to traditional teaching methods. For those saying he's "conveniently leaving out facts," please keep this in mind. He's not trying to "propagate a liberal agenda."

Crash Course writers or Hank, instead of saying "biological" to mean "not transgender". Please use "cisgender". We are not like... un-biological, so it's silly to say that. What are we, robots? :P "Cisgender" is also like.... more objective for lack of a better word? There are people who can explain why this is a good word better than I can. 

Also, I think saying "people who have penises" or "people who have vaginas" is a bit more inclusive and it does not relate gender to genitals and those would have been useful phrases in this video. 

Additionally, sexual orientations DO NOT always match romantic orientations! Sexual and romantic attraction are two separate things and I think that was conflated here. I'm asexual, but I am not aromantic. Aromantic people are not always asexual either. A sexual orientation is what gender you are SEXUALLY attracted to. Not "physically". That is far too broad of a term. Sensual attraction, the desire to touch or kiss someone is also physical, so is aesthetic attraction. 

Crash Course also forgot to include pansexual/panromantic (attraction to all genders and sexes) polysexual (attraction to many genders and sexes) and skoliosexual (exclusive attraction to genderqueer/non-binary and intersex people) as well. But I thought it was cool that you mentioned genderqueer folks and I am genderqueer, so thanks for that at least.

I'm not sure if I agree with the claim that "once you are born, there are no environmental factors that influence your sexual orientation". I don't have sources on hand, unfortunately, but I took a sociology class on Sex and Social Arrangements where we discussed many examples of people describing changes in their sexuality over time. Most of the influences are social, for example: somebody identifies as heterosexual and behaves accordingly in their teens and early adulthood. They then "discover" as they grow older that they are actually attracted to those of the same sex and from then on identify as homosexual. Causes of the initial "confusion" tend to center around social attitudes concerning homosexuality. When a person grows up in a culture that only acknowledges heterosexual desire, people may assume that they, themselves are heterosexual even though this is not the case. It takes time, years even, to break those social constraints and actually reflect on one's own sexuality in a way that is free from bias and assumption.

Alright here is my opinion on the whole "Choice" thing when it comes to orientation.

First things first, I can logically say there there IS a choice, here is why.
First off, I'm going to debunk the idea of a "Gay Gene". Why? Because it doesn't fit in either of the 2 basic schools of scientific thought that I know about (Christian Science IG: Creationism and Athiestic Science IG: Evolution). Christian Science, being rooted in the bible, GENERALLY condemns Homosexuality, so that should already be thrown out. Looking at the other side, a gene that determines sexual preference cannot fit. Why? Because then, obviously, Homosexual people would not exist today because they all died out due to not being able to have offspring and pass their genetics down (the exception being a mutation. But why the hell would you want to tell someone they're a mutant? Unless you have Wolverine Claws. That'd be pretty cool).

Next, there is the idea of how people are nurtured. Let me give you a different idea of something that is nurtured: MUSIC. Some people listen to Music all of their Early Childhood and practice a basic Instrument such as an instrument from the Violin Family, Piano, or the Guitar. Later in life they have a choice to become a Musician. As a Musician I can name SEVERAL people who were raised listening to Music, but will never pursue a serious dedication to music in life.
On the flipside, there are also people who will become brilliant musicians while never having touched Music at all in their early or middle stages in life. This is because they chose to do music.

So, pulling from this analogy, I do not believe people can just "not have a choice" for Sexual Preference. This is because there are some people who are raised in "X Lifestyle" and then either A.) Followed that Lifestyle or B.)Turned around.
On this same strain of thought, some people will be a heterosexual for much of their life and then suddenly turn to a different sexual preference. Obviously this is not common but it does happen because they CHOOSE to.

That is my opinion.

To those in the comments who are asserting that homosexuality is a choice:

The question of whether one's sexual orientation is a choice depends on how sexual orientation is defined. If you are just looking at sexual actions or potential sexual actions (who has sex with whom), then everyone is pansexual in the broadest sense because everyone could choose to or be forced to have sex with anyone, regardless of sexual attraction. But this is a very unuseful definition. If it is defined as being able to be sexually aroused by someone of a given sex or gender, then most people, especially bio-males, would be pansexual—for even if the bio-male is unattracted to whomever is stimulating their genitals and they are not consenting to the sexual act, they still have a high chance of having blood engorge their genitals because of an unconscious reaction to the stimuli. If, however, you include a more psycho-social outlook on sexual orientation, then you can look at one's sexual impulsives and wants, one's sexual actions and history, one's romatic desires and aspirations, and one's culture's views on sexuality and how that has influenced their self-identification. If you use this last definition or tool, then it is more pragmatic and is much closer to what most people instinctually think about sexual orientation—for we are surely not all pansexual. 

Furthermore, if we are going by this definition, then the question cannot be just focused on people who self-identify as homosexual; it would have to be applied to heterosexuals, bisexuals, pansexuals, asexuals, and zoosexuals, too. The question then becomes: Why are we sexually attracted to some people and somethings but not to others? Why aren't we all attracted to everyone of every sex and gender and every species of animal? This question has the tempting answer of "Because that's how we evolved!" but this non-answer answer doesn't give us anything new. In itself, it doesn't have a predictive quality to it. It doesn't explain the biological reasons, if any, for the differences in sexuality—for example, what is the difference, if any, in the brains between people who are heterosexual, bisexual, homosexual, etc.? 

Lastly, just asserting that being gay is a choice is a very narrow and non-pragmatic view. Your own sexuality is equally subject to the criticism that it is just a choice if you go by this view. If sexuality is not at least somewhat open-ended, then most, if not all, people are pansexual. So are you finally going to come out of the closet and embrace your inner queerness and come to Gay Pride, or are you going to admit that sexuality isn't so two dimensional? (You are still welcome to come to Pride, though.)

His sexual orientation segment was filled with a lot of false and dogmatic assertions. Many reputable scientists who are experts in the field have testified that change is possible. Dr. Robert Spitzer, who has been called the most influential psychiatrist of the 20th century (more than 275 publications to his credit), published a peer-reviewed paper in the Archives of Sexual Behavior. The purpose of his study was to evaluate the claim that homosexual orientation is immutable and, consequently, change is impossible.
Spitzer indicated that of the 200 people in the study, many of them increased in the frequency and satisfaction of heterosexual activity. He also noted that, “Almost all of the participants reported substantial changes in the core aspects of sexual orientation, not merely overt behavior.” More significantly, 11% of the men and 37% of the women reported complete change. Spitzer said that these results go beyond, “anecdotal information and provide evidence that reparative therapy is sometimes successful.” Moreover, he concluded that, “This study provides evidence that some gay men and lesbians are able to also change the core features of sexual orientation.”

I think Sexual Orientation is a modern concept that does more harm than good (it creates categories of "others"). My argument: We are just sexual creatures (generally). It is in our nature. We have an instinct to feel sexual pleasure (be it with a sock or a tree or a cucumber). Now how that sexual pleasure is disseminated (pun?) is subjective and not always, but ideally, connected to the people we love and spend our lives with. How we "get off" I would argue - at least from a male perspective - is tied into some form of conditioning. Because if sexuality (and therefore sexual orientation) came naturally to us, then we wouldn't have to learn how to get ourselves and each other off (meaning, we'd all be don juans from birth and there would be no confusion, when you're 13-years-old, about why, when you peed your bed, it came out semi-gelatinous). Or, to put it another way, my friend believed poking his belly button was masturbating and he did this well into his teen years.

I would also say that we are loving creatures and that our sexual desires influence how we define love. But to argue that sexual orientation (the narrow categories that we keep creating) is innate, that we are born with it, doesn't make a lot of evolutionary sense. Evolution does not reward specialists. What makes evolutionary sense is that we are conditioned to find comfort with certain other individuals or groups (that becomes more and more specific through exposure, as we get older), we see this as love, and we apply and inject sex into this feeling therefore fulfilling our very general purpose (to get off - not to procreate...).

Also feel like it's important to note that a) sexual orientation is fluid and often /does/ fluctuate throughout a person's life, and b) it's a very wide and varied spectrum and heterosexuality, homosexuality, bisexuality, and asexuality are not the only orientations out there. Humans are complicated and language hasn't reached the point where it can adequately cover the range of human experiences with sexual orientation. Often there isn't a label that fits an individual perfectly. And also, people on the asexual spectrum can also be heterosexual, homosexual, bisexual, pansexual, etc, the second label describing who they're attracted to in the rare cases that they do experience sexual attraction. Basically, there's a lot to be said on the topic of sexual orientation.

Researchers have provided evidence that gay men report having had less loving and more rejecting fathers, and closer relationships with their mothers, than non-gay men. Some researchers think this may indicate that childhood family experiences are important determinants to homosexuality,[10] or that parents behave this way in response to gender-variant traits in a child.[11][12] Michael Ruse suggests that both possibilities might be true in different cases.[13]
From their research on 275 men in the Taiwanese military, Shu and Lung concluded that "paternal protection and maternal care were determined to be the main vulnerability factors in the development of homosexual males." Key factors in the development of homosexuals were "paternal attachment, introversion, and neurotic characteristics."[14] One study reported that homosexual males reported more positive early relationships with mothers than did homosexual females.[15] A 2000 American twin study showed that familial factors, which may be at least partly genetic, influence (but do not determinate) sexual orientation.[16]
Research also indicates that homosexual men have significantly more siblings than the homosexual women, who, in turn, have significantly more siblings than heterosexual men.[17] A 2006 Danish study compared people who had a heterosexual marriage versus people who had a same-sex marriage. Heterosexual marriage was significantly linked to having young parents, small age differences between parents, stable parental relationships, large numbers of siblings, and late birth order. Children who experience parental divorce are less likely to marry heterosexually than those growing up in intact families. For men, same-sex marriage was associated with having older mothers, divorced parents, absent fathers, and being the youngest child. For women, maternal death during adolescence and being the only or youngest child or the only girl in the family increased the likelihood of same-sex marriage.[10]
